title: Private-Equity-Backed Vista Proppants Files for Bankruptcy
summary: The frac-sand supplier backed by investment firms First Reserve and Ares Capital has filed for bankruptcy, saying it is facing unprecedented problems due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Stocks Waver After Fed Statement
summary: U.S. stocks slumped back toward their morning lows, even after the Federal Reserve projected no interest-rate increases through 2022.

title: Oil Prices Defy Supply-Demand Fundamentals
summary: Rather than surging on supply and demand fundamentals, oil prices have ridden along with other risky assets, such as stocks. Analysts and traders worry the rebound has been too sharp and could prove short-lived.

title: FOMC: Powell’s Conference, Economic Forecasts to Shed Light on Fed’s Thinking
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee wraps up its 2-day meeting today. While Fed officials haven’t locked themselves into a fixed pace of asset purchases, Chairman Jerome Powell has an opportunity at his press conference to clarify the Fed’s bond-buying intentions. And with rates unlikely to go lower, another major element of officials’ policy stance will center on how to communicate their long-run intentions with forward guidance. The Fed will also release economic forecasts for the first time since December, having skipped its usual forecast in March amid uncertainty over the impact of the coronavirus.

title: Trash Burning Ignites as World’s Waste Swells
summary: The growth of incineration, buoyed by moves against landfills, is raising concerns about fumes and impact on recycling efforts.

title: China’s Factory-Gate Deflation Accelerates
summary: Industrial prices fell at their fastest pace in more than four years as the coronavirus pandemic crushed global demand for commodities.

title: Extraction Oil Shares Soar Despite Bankruptcy Warning
summary: The Denver-based driller has said there is a good chance that it will file for bankruptcy, but weak business fundamentals haven’t stopped investors from snapping up its shares.

title: Individuals Roll Dice on Stocks as Veterans Fret
summary: Stuck at home with few entertainment options, more newbies turn to shares; “it’s like a gambling game.”

summary: Oil prices rebounded during the day to end higher, paring some of Monday’s decline amid concern from traders about fuel demand and anticipation of new inventory figures.

title: 1MDB’s Suspected Mastermind Found New Ways to Move Money in Kuwait
summary: The Kuwaiti royal family provided Jho Low means to fend off U.S. and Malaysian investigators who accuse him of masterminding the plunder of Malaysian state investment fund 1MDB.

title: PE Daily: Brynwood Buys Nestlé’s North American Buitoni Unit | Whitehorse Seeks $3 Billion
summary: It’s official: The U.S. economy’s long-term relationship with growth and prosperity ended in February when the economy tipped into a recession, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research. However, the stock markets seem to be betting on a quick reconciliation, with the Nasdaq Composite surging to its first record close in nearly four months on Monday.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Shoppers Risk Gift Card Wipeout | PG&E Eyes Early Debt Issuance | California Resources Preps Ch. 11

title: Fed Debates Yield Caps; Jobs Surprise Highlights Fed’s Forecasting Challenge; Investors Back ECB to Avert Italy Debt Crisis
summary: Fed officials are considering capping Treasury yields for the first time since 1951 to signal their commitment to keeping interest rates low. Policy makers are studying the recent experience of Australia’s central bank, which in March set a target of 0.25% for the country’s three-year bond yield, Nick Timiraos reports. Meanwhile, Friday’s surprisingly strong U.S. jobs data shows how hard it is to make forecasts in these uncharted economic waters, underscoring a challenge for the Fed as it prepares its own projections. And investors are betting that aggressive action from the European Central Bank will help Italy avert a debt crisis.

title: Fed Can’t Find Takers on Its Offer to Buy Corporate Bonds; ECB Expected to Step Up Bond Purchases
summary: The Fed’s promise to buy corporate bonds calmed credit markets in March, but it still hasn’t officially launched the program and companies are reluctant to sign up to it. That’s partly because of the stigma of borrowing from a backstop program, the Journal reports. Some companies also don’t want the Fed buying their bonds now in case another wave of coronavirus roils markets later. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank is expected to unveil some €500 billion in additional bond purchases tomorrow, an increase that would allow it to soak up most of the additional debt that eurozone governments are expected to issue this year.

title: As Iran Lifts Its Lockdown, Virus Cases Return to Peak Level

summary: Bank of England officials have long been skeptical about negative interest rates, but they appear to be softening as economic signals point to the biggest fall in output in Britain in centuries. Negative rates are also in focus in the U.S., where Fed officials continue to express their opposition. Meanwhile, a U.S. budget agency said it could take the economy a decade to recover from the current downturn.

summary: Hertz Global Holdings made its debut in bankruptcy court, and the rental car company said its ability to make payments on its leased vehicle fleet during the pandemic is effectively nil. A Hertz spinoff, rental car company Advantage, also filed for bankruptcy protection. title: EU Plans $2 Trillion Stimulus; Fed’s Beige Book Shows Battered Economy; BOK Cuts Key Rate
summary: The European Union proposed a $2 trillion stimulus package that, if approved, would answer the European Central Bank’s call for a fiscal effort to match its ultra-easy monetary policy. Meanwhile, the Fed’s “beige book” showed the U.S. labor market and consumer spending continued to deteriorate through mid-May. But John Williams of the New York Fed said the economy may be hitting bottom. He also said the Fed is considering yield-curve control, where the central bank actively manages borrowing costs across different maturities. Elsewhere, the Bank of Korea cut its key rate to a record low.

summary: All three major U.S. stock indexes finished the week at least 3% higher, in part driven by optimism that coronavirus vaccines will be available later this year.

title: Oil Price Disruption Eases as Physical Crude Demand Jumps
summary: In a sign that oil markets are returning to relative normality, the once yawning gap between the price of an actual physical barrel of oil and futures prices has narrowed sharply.

title: Coronavirus and the Chernobyl Analogy
summary: Edward Luttwak wrote the book on regime change, and he sees parallels between China’s pandemic response and the Soviet Union’s late years.

title: Chuck Yates, Co-Head of Kayne Anderson’s Energy-Focused Funds, Exits the Firm
summary: Chuck Yates has left Kayne Anderson Capital Advisors after spending almost two decades at the private-equity firm, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Clarida Says Fed’s Inflation, Employment Goals Under Threat; BOJ Steps Up Support; India Cuts Rates; China Scraps GDP Target
summary: Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said the coronavirus pandemic poses the most serious threat “in our lifetimes” to the central bank’s goals of maintaining strong employment and stable prices. The Bank of Japan increased its support for business financing to about $700 billion, paralleling the Fed in expanding its tool kit to deal with the pandemic. India’s central bank cut interest rates in an unscheduled move. And, for the first time since 1994, China’s government decided not to publish a target for annual GDP growth.

title: Gabon's Government to Back Coffee Prices Amid Coronavirus
The Daily Shot: Don’t Expect a V-Shaped Recovery, Says Bank of America
Oil Rally Continues With Supply Cuts Boosting Sentiment
summary: Oil prices climbed, advancing for the sixth consecutive session with producers curtailing output in response to ultralow crude prices and the coronavirus crisis.

title: Natural Gas Follows Global Prices Lower -- Market Talk
Harold Hamm, Fracking Pioneer, Faces a Career Reckoning
summary: The founder of oil giant Continental Resources revolutionized the industry and helped usher in the U.S. energy boom. Now he’s slashing production and ripping up delivery contracts to try to survive the price collapse from coronavirus shutdowns.

title: Gabon's Government Promises Decent Prices for Cocoa Beans
These High-End Home Offices Mean Business
summary: With telecommuting on the rise, homeowners are carving out luxurious work-from-home spaces.

title: Fed Mulls How to Signal Rate Plans; Bullard Not Worried About Second Virus Wave; U.K. Sells Bond at Negative Yield
summary: The Fed’s coming policy discussions are turning on how to signal its plans for keeping interest rates low. One strategy would tie future plans to achieving specific economic outcomes, while another would be to give calendar-based guidance, such as saying the central bank will hold rates low until some date in the future, Fed meeting minutes show. Meanwhile, St. Louis Fed leader James Bullard said he isn’t too worried about a second wave of the coronavirus because he believes people would be faster to respond to the threat. And the British government sold its first bond with a negative yield after Bank of England policy makers kept the possibility of negative rates on the table.

title: Britain’s Big Dividend Reset
summary: Cash returns once seen as sacrosanct have been cut during this crisis and seem unlikely to rebound soon.

title: The Daily Shot: Fears of U.S. Renters Skipping Payments En Masse Appear Overblown
U.S. Stocks Stage Rebound Rally
summary: Major indexes clawed back after Tuesday’s losses on optimism about the prospects for a global economic recovery. The energy sector led the S&P 500, climbing about 4% as oil prices rose.

title: Wheat Rally Extends on Black Sea Drought
Iran’s Gasoline for Maduro
summary: Tankers are headed for Caracas. Will the U.S. give them a pass?

title: U.S. Seeks Ways to Halt Iran’s Oil Sales to Venezuela
summary: The Trump administration is weighing new sanctions and other legal steps as it seeks to block Iranian oil exports to Venezuela, according to U.S. officials.

title: Brazil’s Coronavirus Crisis Disrupts Iron-Ore Market; Prices Surge
summary: The deadly outbreak in one of the world’s biggest producers of iron ore has disrupted global supplies, just as demand from China is revving up, pushing the price of the steel ingredient to a seven-month high.

title: Deflation Hit Canada in April
summary: Canada’s annual inflation rate sank into negative territory in April, the first year-over-year price decline in over a decade, largely attributable to a sizable drop in gasoline.

title: Russia’s Economy Suffers Double Hit From Oil Slump and Coronavirus
summary: As the pandemic spreads, Russia finds a shortfall in oil revenue is hurting its ability to offer the kind of emergency support provided in the West.

title: The Daily Shot: Sources of Funding for Small Businesses
What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Stocks Finish Lower After Late Drop
summary: The Dow industrials and S&P 500 slid in the last hour of trading following a Monday advance that was the biggest gain for blue-chip shares in over a month.

title: Return of Car Traffic Fuels Oil Surge
summary: Prices are staging a furious comeback from last month’s collapse, lifted by record supply cuts and a pickup in global fuel demand that many investors hope heralds a swift economic recovery.

title: Soaring Silver Attracts Investors
summary: Silver prices are surging, making the metal one of the market’s best-performing assets in the second quarter, with investors seeking havens that can hold their value during times of economic uncertainty.

title: Hornbeck Offshore Files Prearranged Chapter 11 to Cut Debt
summary: Hornbeck Offshore Services, an operator of oil supply and support vessels with more than $1 billion in long-term debt, filed for bankruptcy to implement a prepackaged chapter 11 plan that will cut its debt.

title: Powell, Mnuchin to Take Questions on Lending Programs; Investors Bet on ECB With Southern European Bond Purchases
summary: Jerome Powell and Steven Mnuchin are set to appear by videoconference before a Senate committee this morning as part of regular testimony required by the $2 trillion economic-relief package. Lawmakers are likely to ask Mr. Mnuchin whether he is prepared to lose the money Congress provided to ensure credit is widely available. In testimony prepared for the panel, Mr. Powell said the Fed will use its “full range of tools to support the economy." Meanwhile, investors are lapping up a record amount of Southern European sovereign debt, counting on the European Central Bank to backstop the riskiest bonds.

title: FBI Probe Ties Florida Attack to al Qaeda, Faults Apple
summary: A Saudi aviation student who killed three people last year at a Florida Navy base had extensive ties to al Qaeda, top U.S. law-enforcement officials said Monday as they accused Apple Inc. of stalling the probe by refusing to help unlock the shooter’s phones..

title: Newsletter: U.S. Companies Bet on China’s Economic Future
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal.

title: The Daily Shot: Fund Managers Still Positioned Defensively, Fueling the Rally
The Palestinians Need to Make Bold Moves
summary: Facing crisis, they should follow Arafat’s example by agreeing to negotiations.

title: Moderna’s Vaccine Hope
summary: The biotech firm says its Phase 1 trial shows promising results.

title: U.S. Stocks Rally As Hopes for New Virus Vaccine Build
summary: The Dow industrials surged 3.9%, recovering ground following their biggest weekly percentage drop in nearly two months.

title: Soybeans Climb on Covid Vaccine Hopes

summary: The most wagered-upon oil prices these days are for crude bobbing at sea on big tankers—or even still in the ground.

title: AGS WEEK AHEAD: European Forecasts Show Continued Dry Weather; Coffee Market Watching Brazil Virus Numbers
PE Daily: A Distressed Debt Bonanza | Shark Tank Startup Lands $1 Million | Conn. Pension Gets PE Pacing Boost
summary: As another week kicks off, the pace of traditional private-equity deal activity has continued to slow, but one group of investors, namely distressed-debt and special-situation fund managers, are raring to go. As William Louch reports, distressed debt firms aim to raise a record amount of money to capitalize on dislocation created by the coronavirus pandemic. But they aren’t the only ones looking to jump on opportunities. The Connecticut Retirement Plans and Trust Funds aims to commit another $600 million to the asset class over the next three years, as it looks to capitalize on market dislocations.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: J.C. Penney Stares Down Liquidation Risk | Quorum’s Ch. 11 Exit Delayed | Imerys Unit’s Mass Tort Settlement
summary: The coronavirus pandemic claimed its highest-profile corporate victim yet when J.C. Penney Co. filed for bankruptcy, pressuring the department store chain to settle quickly with creditors. Hospital operator Quorum Health Corp. hit a speed bump on its path out of chapter 11 over disputes around government bailout money. France’s Imerys SA put its North American talc business up for sale as part of a larger settlement of personal injury claims.

title: Soybeans Form Quiet, Inside Day -- Technical Analysis
The Daily Shot: The U.S. Economy to Shrink by Nearly a Third This Quarter

summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Finally, the Low Prices We Deserve
summary: The economic crash is ‘unflating’ decades-old bubbles in several stagnant industries.

title: Oil Becomes a Risky Game for Saudis
summary: Lower prices put U.S. producers at a disadvantage, but they also cost Riyadh and imperil ties with the U.S.

title: Saudi Sovereign-Wealth Fund Buys Stakes in Facebook, Boeing, Disney
summary: In the coronavirus pandemic’s financial fallout, Saudi Arabia’s sovereign-wealth fund has emerged as one of the world’s biggest bargain hunters, taking minority stakes worth billions of dollars in America corporations.

title: Wary of U.S. Crude, Investors Bet on Gasoline and Brent
summary: Some fund managers think it is safer, and will prove more lucrative, to invest in refined-oil products or in Brent, a blend of crudes produced in the North Sea. The hottest trade right now: gasoline.

title: Blackstone’s Gavilan Resources Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Gavilan Resources, an oil and gas company formed by buyout firm Blackstone Group, has filed for bankruptcy protection, a victim of the collapse in energy prices and a long-running commercial dispute with a rival Texas shale driller.

title: Emerging and Growth Markets, May 16th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: After Devastating Contraction, Glimmers of Growth Emerge
summary: There are signs the economic contraction caused by the pandemic, the steepest since the Great Depression, has bottomed out and a tentative recovery may be under way.

title: What Happens When a Lender’s Borrowers All Lose Their Jobs at Once?
summary: Almost a third of the nation’s credit unions are tied to a single employer, industry or other association. Those serving customers who have simultaneously suffered mass layoffs or furloughs due to the coronavirus pandemic are grappling with how to respond.

title: RV Vacations: The Safest Way to Travel This Summer
summary: Planes are grounded. Hotels shut. After a spring spent cooped-up, many Americans are renting recreational vehicles to get away. Here’s a guide.

title: Stocks Recover, But Finish the Week With Losses
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 rose Friday, but not enough to score gains for the week as investors weighed the possibility of renewed trade tensions, along with weak data on U.S. consumer spending.

title: Oil Logs Big Weekly Gain Ahead of Contract Expiration
summary: Oil prices rose Friday, logging a weekly gain with global fuel demand starting to rise as the world reopens for business.

title: Ultra Petroleum Files for Bankruptcy for Second Time in Four Years
summary: One of the largest oil and natural-gas drillers in Wyoming filed for bankruptcy after struggling with nearly $2 billion of debt left on its books after its previous restructuring amid a historic slump in energy prices.

title: ‘Overhedging’ Oil Prices Lands Some Global Airlines in Trouble
summary: As global airlines reel from the huge drop-off in business caused by the coronavirus, some face a second hit from this year’s historic plunge in oil prices.

title: Germany Enters Recession but Fares Better Than Neighbors
summary: Germany fell into recession in the first quarter, shrinking at its second-fastest pace since reunification as the coronavirus pandemic hurt everything from retailers to auto exporters, but its economy is expected to fare better than its neighbors in 2020.

title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: TV Shopping, IPO Trend, Home Ergonomics
summary: Television shopping channels have avoided the woes that befell the media and retail industries; the majority of money raised by U.S. IPOs was for companies whose purpose is to fund acquisitions, and working from home has taken a toll on workers backs and necks.

title: The Daily Shot: Nearly a Quarter of U.S. Workers Filed for Unemployment Since March 20th
Oil Demand Mounts Comeback as Coronavirus Restrictions Ease
summary: Oil consumption is rising again in those parts of the world emerging from coronavirus lockdowns, helping to alleviate a global glut and rebalance a market stymied by months of low demand and a devastating rout that saw prices drop by as much as two-thirds this year.

title: Soybean Futures Slip as Planting Weather Looks Promising
Bank of Mexico Cuts Interest Rates Again
summary: The Bank of Mexico cut interest rates Thursday for the third time in two months as the outlook for the economy worsened.

title: Fed’s Powell Warns of a Slow Rebound; Fed Isn’t Looking at Negative Rates
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped more than 500 points yesterday after Jerome Powell said more stimulus from Washington could be needed to support the U.S. economic recovery. The Fed Chairman said the economic outlook is “highly uncertain and subject to significant downside risks." Global markets continued to decline this morning. Mr. Powell also said the Fed isn’t considering cutting its benchmark rate below zero, a remark that prompted a comeback from President Trump.

title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Investment Banks, Tax Breaks, Meat Shortage
summary: The largest U.S. and European investment banks saw headcounts decline despite banner first-quarter results; companies in diverse industries have reaped billions in tax breaks to ride out the economic slump, and sellers of meat alternatives looked to take advantage of the meat shortage.

title: The Daily Shot: Americans Are Taking Money From Retirement Accounts
Intelsat Files for Bankruptcy Ahead of Spectrum Auction
summary: Satellite operator Intelsat filed for bankruptcy protection after falling short of the cash it needed to make airwaves available to be sold to wireless operators in a coming government auction.

title: Powell Says Washington Will Need to Spend More to Battle Downturn
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell urged the White House and Congress to spend more money to ensure their initial response to the coronavirus-induced economic contraction isn’t wasted amid evidence that recovery will take longer than first thought.

title: Norwegian Fund Excludes Large Canadian Oil Producers
summary: Norway’s sovereign-wealth fund said it is blacklisting four of Canada’s largest oil producers from its trillion-dollar portfolio, citing high carbon emissions from their operations.

title: Investment Giants Want Exchanges to Enforce Labeling System for ETFs
summary: BlackRock, State Street Global Advisors and some other large money managers are asking exchanges to enforce a more narrow definition of exchange-traded funds.

title: Coronavirus Projected to Keep Weighing on Oil Demand
summary: Global oil demand is expected to drop 18% this quarter from a year earlier as coronavirus lockdowns continue to hammer the global economy, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said.

title: California Resources in Talks for Up to $600 Million Bankruptcy Loan
summary: California Resources is in discussions with lenders around a financing package of up to $600 million to carry the oil company through a planned bankruptcy proceeding, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Soaring Prices, Rotting Crops: Coronavirus Triggers Global Food Crisis
summary: Processing and transportation breakdowns and panic buying are threatening vulnerable nations. “You can have a food crisis with lots of food. That’s the situation we’re in,” said a senior economist at the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Bain-Backed Restaurant Chain Files for Bankruptcy | Dura Auto Creditors Seek Answers | Pioneer Energy to Exit Bankruptcy Under Modified Plan
summary: The operator of the Bamboo Sushi and QuickFish restaurant chains, backed by Bain Capital’s impact investing fund, filed for bankruptcy with hopes of finding a buyer. Dura Automotive creditors want answers about why potential buyers walked away from the auto-parts maker. And Pioneer Energy won approval for a modified chapter 11 exit plan after bondholders, spooked by plummeting oil prices, moved to back out of the prepackaged deal.

title: What to Expect from Powell’s Speech; Fed’s Barkin, Mester, Harker Discuss Recovery Prospects; Bond ETFs Climb
summary: The Peterson Institute for International Economics, a Washington think tank, will host a virtual speech by Jerome Powell today. Look for him to talk about the downside risks to the economy. As Nick Timiraos writes, the event is a chance for the Fed chairman to gently deliver a take-your-medicine message to Republicans in Congress and the White House who are showing signs of fatigue over economic relief measures. Yesterday saw three other senior Fed leaders give their views on the prospects for an eventual recovery. Meanwhile, U.S. corporate bond exchange-traded funds rose after the Fed said it would start buying the securities.

title: Bank Resurrected During Crisis Takes Fresh Hits
summary: Dutch bank ABN Amro said massive losses in oil and derivatives trading pushed it into a loss in the most recent quarter.

title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Oil Storage Peak,  Crime-Scene Cleaners, Tourist Destinations
summary: Signs appeared that oil storage companies have seen their peak profitability; crime-scene cleaners have seen a surge in demand from retailers, and tourist destinations tried to figure out how to reopen safely.

title: The Daily Shot: Disinflationary Pressures Are Building
India Tests the Limits of Public Finance in Emerging Markets
summary: India must spend far more to rescue its economy from the ravages of the pandemic and the lockdown, which may involve the central bank funding much of the budget deficit.

title: Easing Oversupply Fears Lift Oil Prices
summary: Oil prices climbed, a sign that production cutbacks and easing pressure on storage facilities are lifting traders’ hopes for battered energy markets.

title: U.S. Stocks Extend Fall as Dow Drops More Than 450 Points
summary: U.S. stocks tumbled, giving up modest gains in a selloff that picked up momentum in the afternoon.

title: Coronavirus Lockdowns Trigger Big Drop in Consumer Prices
summary: U.S. consumer prices in April posted their largest monthly decline since the last recession after energy prices collapsed and efforts to contain the new coronavirus disrupted demand for a wide array of goods and services.

title: Pioneer Energy Wins Confirmation of Modified Chapter 11 Plan
summary: The oil-field services company has won court approval for a modified chapter 11 exit plan after plummeting oil prices forced its lenders and bondholders back to the bargaining table to renegotiate their “prepackaged” restructuring deal.

title: USDA Report: World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates
Aramco Shares Offer a Stake in the Kingdom
summary: Aramco’s performance this year should dispel lingering hopes that buying shares in the petroleum giant is anything other than an investment in the Saudi state.

title: Private-Equity Owners of Oil Tanks See Little Gain From Surging Demand for Storage
summary: Energy infrastructure investors that previously invested hundreds of millions of dollars in oil tanks and other storage infrastructure aren’t capitalizing on the boom as traders look for places to keep cheap oil that they hope to sell for a profit in the future.

title: PE Daily: Firms Miss Out on Soaring Oil Storage Demand | U.S. Plans to Invest in Emerging-Market Funds | PNC Aims to Cash In on BlackRock
summary: With so much criticism heaped on the private-equity industry in recent months, it may surprise some that a federal agency aims to start investing millions of dollars into PE funds. As our Preeti Singh reports, the agency plans to use taxpayer dollars to invest as a limited partner in PE funds focused on emerging markets, instead of lending them money as in the past.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Neiman Is Burning Through Cash | Washington Prime REIT in Debt Talks | Some PG&E Fire Victims Are Questioning Lawyer’s Financial Ties
summary: Neiman Marcus Group Ltd. expects to burn through $300 million in cash before it is able to reopen its stores. Mall operator Washington Prime Group Inc., its business battered by the Covid-19 pandemic, is in talks with creditors about a potential debt restructuring and warned it may not survive if the talks fail. And some PG&E Corp. fire victims are taking a second look at the personal-injury lawyer who played a leading role in arranging a proposed $13.5 billion settlement with the bankrupt utility.

title: New York Fed to Buy ETFs; Fed’s Evans Sees a Silver Lining in the Second Half
summary: In a milestone for the central bank, the New York Fed said it would start buying bond exchange-traded funds. The Fed sees them as a quick way of channeling money into credit markets, Michael S. Derby reports. Meanwhile, Chicago Fed leader Charles Evans sounded a cautiously optimistic note about the prospects for a recovery, saying it’s reasonable to expect the U.S. economy to resume growing, albeit modestly, in the second half of the year.

title: Their Ship Came in as Oil Prices Crashed
summary: Oil contango is easing and signals that storage companies have seen their peak profitability.

title: Aramco Profit Is Hit Hard by Collapse in Oil Prices
summary: Saudi Aramco said its first-quarter profit fell and it would cut spending this year, underscoring the twin impact of an oil-price rout and the coronavirus pandemic on the kingdom’s worsening finances.

title: China Economic Data Indicate V-Shaped Recovery Is Unlikely
summary: China’s factory-gate prices contracted in April, falling by the steepest margin in four years, as manufacturers struggled with deflationary pressures from the coronavirus pandemic, which has crimped demand both at home and abroad.

title: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Iran Leverages Oil to Court Other U.S. Rivals During Pandemic
summary: Isolated in the midst of a global pandemic, Iran is using its sanctioned oil and energy expertise to garner favor and financial gain from two other nations shunned by the U.S.: Syria and Venezuela.

title: PNC Financial to Exit Investment in BlackRock
summary: Regional bank PNC Financial plans to sell its stake in money management giant BlackRock in a secondary offering.

title: Shale Driller Chesapeake Energy Warns Its Future in Peril
summary: Chesapeake Energy warned it may not be able to stay in business as weak oil and natural-gas prices imperil a yearslong effort to pay down hefty debt.

title: Oil Prices Fall as Demand Concerns Outweigh Supply Cuts
summary: Oil prices closed lower after a volatile session, pausing a recent rebound even after Saudi Arabia and other producers said they will deepen supply cuts to support beleaguered energy markets.

title: Egypt Gets $2.77 Billion IMF Loan as Coronavirus Hurts Economy
summary: The International Monetary Fund approved Monday a $2.77 billion loan to Egypt in an attempt to prevent economic collapse in the Middle East’s most populous nation due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Emerging and Growth Markets, May 9th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: Wanted: Somewhere, Anywhere, to Store Lots of Cheap Oil
summary: Storage schemes get creative, with would-be investors looking to sock it away in giant pools, caves or anywhere else they can until prices rebound. ‘Who wants to help your dad do this crazy stuff?’

title: Saudi Arabia Imposes Austerity Measures as Its Economy Founders
summary: The kingdom said it would triple its value-added tax rate and eliminate allowances for state workers, adopting austerity measures aimed at boosting state finances battered by the coronavirus and lower oil prices.

title: While Big Oil Pulls Back, Mexico’s President Bets on Pemex
summary: As global oil companies try to make savings, Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador is focusing much of the country’s limited financial firepower on its state-run oil company.

title: The Daily Shot: U.S. Job Losses Substantially Worse Than the Headline Figures Suggest
The Emerging-Market Debt Trap
summary: Emerging-market debt sold off aggressively in March and has recovered less than other asset classes. It remains cheap for good reasons.

title: Pandemic Sparks Slump in Electricity Prices
summary: Wall Street trading floors have emptied. Spring has arrived north of the equator. Oil and gas markets have cratered. The result is a precipitous decline in electricity prices.

title: Who Needs Oil When Even OPEC Telecommutes?
summary: Changes wrought by the pandemic could dampen global demand for years and kill American shale.
